title: 112_hr6224
content: The Act titled "Providing Assistance with the Paperwork from Excessive Regulations Act of 2012" suspends fines for first-time paperwork violations by small business concerns. The "Paperwork Reduction Act" amends Section 3506 of title 44, United States Code to suspend fines for first-time paperwork violations by small business concerns, unless the violation poses serious harm to the public interest. The "Paperwork Reduction Act" suspends fines for first-time paperwork violations by small businesses, unless the violation poses a danger to public health or safety. The agency may choose not to impose a civil fine on a small business if a violation is corrected within 5 business days of notification, especially if the violation poses a danger to public health or safety. Factors considered include the nature and seriousness of the violation. The agency may choose not to impose a civil fine on a small business if a violation is corrected within 5 business days of notification, especially if the violation poses a danger to public health or safety. Factors considered include the nature and seriousness of the violation, whether the small business has made efforts to comply and remedy the violation, and if they have gained an economic benefit from it. If a small business does not correct a violation that poses a danger to public health or safety within 5 business days, the agency must notify Congress within 60 days of imposing a civil fine. This rule does not apply to first-time violations by small businesses regarding information collection requirements. The head of an agency shall not consider violations of information collection requirements by another agency when making a determination.
